results.title: Kevin is fine
results.creator_credit: Gordon Glenn and The Film House
results.brief_description: A woman living in an isolated farm house in North Western Victoria believes her child has a learning deficiency. Her own fears and the attitude of her husband have prevented her from seeking help. Covers a series of events which lead her to take action. Cast: Nancy Black, Ross Williams.

results.title: Kerouac's road: a Franco-American odyssey
results.creator_credit: Hermenegilde Chiasson, Eric Michel and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Jack Kerouac, the novelist who revolutionised the form of American fiction and journalism, was born to a family of French-Canadians in exile and did not begin to understand English until he was six. Alienation, a quest for transcendence and the need to discover a new language would ultimately define his art. Through dramatised excerpts, period footage and candid interviews, this film shows how Kerouac’s restless seeking as a literary bohemian embodied a larger Franco-American pattern of emigration and displacement.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermenegilde Chiasson, Eric Michel and ONF | NFB

results.title: Kerala: land of lagoons
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, Ezra Mir and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: Surveys the scenic beauty of the southwestern Indian state of Kerala and the colorful festivities observed by its people. Includes scene of the celebration of Onam, an old festival of Kerala, a boat race on Periyar Lake, a temple festival, and the famous dance-drama Kathakali.

results.title: Kerala
results.creator_credit: T.A. Abraham, Ezra Mir and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A picture of Kerala State in south-west India. A flat fertile land with many waterways supporting a dense population; many crops including spices, for which the district was known to the Arabs and Phoenicians; Vasco da Gama and the history of Kerala; the Byzantine influence in the city of Trivandrum; paintings and sculptures in the museum and much more including the life and customs of the people.

results.title: Keppoch Estate
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Keppoch Estate, to the north of Coonawarra, the film discusses the development of a new wine area by Thomas Hardy and Sons, a family tradition in fine wine making since 1853.

results.title: Kepler and his work
results.creator_credit: Education Foundation for Visual Arts and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: Kepler’s life story, his discovery of the three Laws of Planetary Motion and work of optics. Contemporary prints illustrate his early life and education at the University of Tubingen; concepts of planetary motion held at the time, and the way Kepler’s work altered them; work in Prague leading to the Laws of Planetary Motion; study of optics, astronomical calculations and other publications; his last years, overshadowed by the Thirty Year’s War.

results.title: Kenya today
results.creator_credit: Gordon Bradley and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: The progress made in Kenya since the Mau Mau uprisings of 1952. Kikuyu natives concentrated in villages for protection - the beginning of land consolidation and planned farming. Many Kikuyu work on large European farms growing sisal, or coffee, Kenya’s main exports. The co-existence of Africans, Indians, Arabs, and Europeans poses complex racial problems.

results.title: Kennedy: years of charisma
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Murray-Brown, New York Times Productions and Nielsen-Ferns International
results.brief_description: Shows John F Kennedy’s election to the White House. Tells that in his life he was popular, drew much praise, inspired affection, and had as many critics as most politicians do, but that in death he became a hero and a legend wrapped in mythology and sentimentality. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Kemira: diary of a strike
results.brief_description: The first Australian film to document the organisation of a strike and its unfolding over time from an “insider” perspective. In September 1982, at the height of the economic recession, Australian Iron and Steel, a subsidiary of BHP, announced its intention to retrench 400 miners from the six coal pits which supplied the company’s Wollongong steelworks. Kemira was the worst affected pit where 206 workers (two-thirds of the workforce) were to lose their jobs. A confronting account of an important historical and political event.

results.title: Kelvin Coe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
One of Australia’s most admired and acclaimed dancers, Kelvin Coe speaks about his long association with the Australian Ballet, which began when he was employed as a student apprentice at the age of sixteen. He recalls the many dancers who inspired and influenced him, including Erik Bruhn, Rudolf Nureyev, Kathleen Geldard and Lucette Aldous and his partnership with Marilyn Rowe Maver. Coe discusses the relationship between the dancer and the choreographer and his work as a teacher with the Australian Ballet School. Research and interview by James Murdoch.
